title: Playing video is extremely choppy
content:
The problem: When I try to watch video in firefox, it hitches up. The audio keeps playing fine but it'll freeze up on an frame for ~10 seconds then jump to where the audio is at and freeze again. On lower quality videos, it's relatively better but there's still choppy to the point of unwatchable. Chrome and Edge can both play the higher quality videos with 0 problems.

Things I've tried: Restarting the computer Reinstalling Firefox "Refreshing" Firefox Clearing my cache Launching Firefox in safe mode Changing media.benchmark.vp9.fps Reinstalling my graphics drivers Turning accelerated processing off Decreasing the content processing limit Probably some other stuff I'm forgetting at the moment

I've tried to switch over to firefox multiple times over the last year or so, and every time I have this issue and eventually just give in and go back to chrome. I'm on Windows 10 on an old-ish laptop, not sure if that helps.

title: Saved password "problem" since update
content:
(Maybe it is me - it usually is)

I have saved logins saved in FF. There is also a master password.

This problem is happening more and more:

I load FF and no "Enter master password" requester.

I start browsing. Eventually I get to a site which requires a log in.

NOTHING!

So I know FF has it saved - and password protected - but FF has decided to not ask me for the master password so I (or it) can then enter the saved details.

Today - being the last straw - I come here and (of course) this saved log in wasn't accessible. I fell back on the secondary system and logged in. FF asks me if I want to save this log in. (Maybe luckily) I said YES - but I am sure it is already saved - do I then get the "Enter master password" requester.

This is annoying as I have a few pages which I access very frequently password locked. It is annoying when I get to them - even tried reloading the page, if that will bring up the requester. It doesn't - FF won't/can't log in for me.

title: FF is leaking my User Agent with privacy.resistFingerprinting=true
content:
I have privacy.resistFingerprinting set to true, and the HTTP_USERAGENT field comes out as fingerprint resistant, but the javascript object "window.navigator" still leaks the non-resistant UA. Simple demo code is listed below.

[code] <meta charset="utf-8"> <title>Leaked User Agent</title> <script> alert(window.navigator && window.navigator.userAgent ? window.navigator.userAgent : ""); </script> /code

I tried clicking somewhere else on the screen, clicking outside of Firefox to take the focus off of it, opening another program altogether, clicking on the various icons next to the address bar. title: Downloaded PDF files are opened in Firefox again
content:
I'm using Firefox 78.0.2 on Manjaro Linux and on Windows 10. The same happens for both OS.

A few days ago (not at the latest update, but maybe the one before that?), the behaviour regarding PDF files changed.

Before: When clicking on a link to a PDF file, it was opened in Firefox. When I downloaded it and then clicked on the file in the "Downloads" section, the local, downloaded file was opened in my system's PDF viewer. After: After downloading, when I click on the file in the "Downloads" section, the local, downloaded file is opened in Firefox again.

The system default for opening PDF files has not changed, i.e., when I open a PDF file locally from the file system, it opens in the PDF viewer, and not in Firefox.

Changing how PDF files should be opened in "Settings - Content" does change the behaviour for both cases simultaneously. Is there any way to change this back to the old behaviour?
creator: Harmageddon

title: Firefox Tracking Protection and extension overlap?
content:
There is no shortage of privacy protection plugins, which I consider to be a good thing However, Firefox also has tracking protection on board itself. This leaves me wondering if and how much overlap there is between these privacy protection plugins and Firefox tracking protection and if having both or multiple of these enabled, isn't simply overkill?

To illustrate, I have tracking protection set to strict. In addition, I use EFF Privacy Badger, uBlock Origin, NoScript and DuckDuckGo Privacy Essentials.

If I have Firefox tracking protection set to strict, do I still need Privacy Badger, uBlock Origin and DuckDuckGo Privacy Essentials? These seem to cover the same functionality but one may be better than the other. How do I know which to choose? (NoScript is more a security feature, so that's another matter).
creator: joopberis

Any thoughts as to how I can get it to respond only when I request a page/site with relevant details stored. Thanks Baz

title: Lost My Tabs TWICE!
content: I had to reset my password for Firefox sync and therefore I had to log back in in all my Firefox browsers on multiple machines. Well, I ended up losing all my tabs after closing Firefox and re-opening. What the heck is that about?! Then I finally logged back in on another machine just tonight and the same thing! This time the loss of tabs was even more detrimental! I then go back to the browser I lost first and I saw the restore previous option was unchecked. Why would that option be unchecked if I didn't uncheck it?! Come on, Mozilla! This just really makes me want to stay the heck away from Firefox and just deal with Edge and Safari because I can't deal with this type of unreliability. Is there any way I can restore my tabs without reverting my machine back to an earlier time or extracting just my profile data from a snapshot?
creator: higherstature

title: Failure for WebRTC's GetUserMedia to load local USB Wecam
content:
When testing for WebRTC compatibility on my Fedora linux system using "WebRTC troubleshooter" or "GetUserMedia command tester" I have 2 problems as follows:

1. The permissions window only shows the option of "default device"

2. The USB camera is refusing to be accepted as "the default device".

Upon inspection of the "troubleshooter" problem analysis it states that GetUserMedia failed sue to a "ReferenceError" (see attached photo of screen)

Details: H/W = Raspberry Pi 4B (4GB RAM), S/W = Fedora 32, Desktop = KDE and LXDE (both tried separately), Firefox 78.0.2(64bit) Info: v4l2-ctl --list devices shows the device as /dev/video0; /dev/video1; /dev/media0. Also, I am able to obtain a working camera with "cheese" and "xawtv"

As I am a novice to Linux systems and I want to use a WebRTC connection for testing purposes using Firefox, I would appreciate some assistance to know what is blocking the USB Webcam from being selected as a source and why Firefox is not showing the name of actual devices in the permissions window. Thank you in advance.

title: password and login autofill

Every time I close the browser, the preference reverts back. There is no "save" option after I check the box either.

title: Firefox returning exact same secured generated password for multiple sites and logins
content:
For some reason, I'm getting the exact same "securely generated password" on multiple sites and logins.

Nothing I do (neither right-click nor anything else) causes the password to regenerate.

For some sites, it works perfectly. For example, when I signed up for here, it happily generated a new password.

However, if I go over to GitHub, for example, and attempt to change my password, I get *exactly* the same (old) password over and over with no way to regenerate.

Perhaps it's a change vs new issue?

Or am I simply doing something wrong?

Thanks.

(OS X 10.14.6 with Firefox 78.0.2)
creator: disp1_mozilla
